message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of recurrent bronchiectasis, chronic sinusitis, and foul-smelling stools suggest cystic fibrosis, which is confirmed by genetic testing. The most common complication associated with cystic fibrosis is infertility due to blocked sperm ducts. Options A, C, and D are not typically associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest cystic fibrosis, which is confirmed by genetic testing. Infertility is a common complication associated with cystic fibrosis, as it can affect both male and female fertility. The other options are not associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest cystic fibrosis, which can be confirmed with genetic testing. Infertility is a common complication associated with cystic fibrosis due to the thickened cervical mucus making it difficult for sperm to reach the egg. The other options are not associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of foul-smelling stools and recurrent bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis suggest the most likely diagnosis is cystic fibrosis. Infertility is the most common complication associated with cystic fibrosis, which is caused by the blockage of the vas deferens in men and thick cervical mucus in women.

The patient’s symptoms, including foul-smelling stools, recurrent bronchiectasis, and chronic sinusitis, suggest cystic fibrosis as the most likely diagnosis. Infertility is the most common complication associated with cystic fibrosis in males due to bilateral absence or obstruction of the vas deferens. The other options are not associated with cystic fibrosis.

Infertility is the most common complication associated with CF due to the thickening of cervical mucus, which makes it difficult for sperm to reach the egg. The other options are not associated with CF.

Option A is associated with Marfan syndrome, option C with HIV, and option D with cystic fibrosis in newborns.

The most common complication associated with CF is infertility, as the condition affects the development and function of the reproductive system. None of the other options are associated with CF.
